results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

Their children having grown up, this film captures Les and Dorothy enjoying a holiday in New Zealand.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Dorothy Nixon and two companions are part of a travel trip as indicated by their name tags
00:00:17:00 sign for ‘trial plots’ as part of a nursery in New Zealand, followed by Dorothy enjoying some views of public gardens
00:01:12:00 sign for ‘Cockayne Memorial Garden’ in honour of Dr Leonard Cockayne, a significant botanist in New Zealand
00:01:31:00 a conservatory in the gardens
00:02:00:00 a large lake amongst hills and a ship, a yacht and boats
00:02:13:00 views toward snowy covered mountains and looking down over a town from a higher vantage point followed by more snowy mountain tops
00:03:07:00 a tourist bus stopped at a roadside lookout point followed by more lakeside scenery
00:03:30:00 filming the mountains and landscape from inside a small plane
00:04:19:00 views of the motel accommodation for the travellers
00:05:10:00 sign for the ‘Omarama Motel Lodge’
00:05:34:00 a peacock, several small deer
00:06:01:00 sign ‘Welcome to Lake Manapouri’
00:06:20:00 a waterfall and tourists on a walk bridge over ‘Falls Creek’
00:06:45:00 filming from a bus as it travels through mountains
00:07:19:00 filming among fellow tourists in a boat on a river taking in the spectacular views of waterfalls and mountains
00:09:42:00 a steam train comes into view on a country track followed by views of houses and trees across a lake
00:10:18:00 looking at the front of a paddle steamer
00:10:40:00 filming from a sky lift as it travels up a hill followed by views over a town below
00:11:11:00 looking at the sky lift as it travels up
00:11:24:00 tourists walk over a bridge looking down at a fast moving creek or river
00:12:52:00 a helicopter landing
00:13:52:00 views of ‘Shantytown’, a tourist attraction on the South Island
00:14:41:00 on board a tourist boat on a lake
00;15:21:00 sign for ‘New Zealand Electricity’ after views of the plant
00:15:27:00 various ‘Wharenui’ (Maori meeting house) followed by views of hot springs
00:16:16:00 on a light plane travelling over a lake looking down on a seaplane
00:17:12:00 memorial to ‘Michael Joseph Savage 1872 – 1940’
00:17:20:00 traditional Maori dance performance
00:18:04:00 scenes of the rolling waves around the rocky coast
00:18:28:00 the travellers gather at the sign for ‘Tane Mahuta (Lord of the Forest)’, a very tall tree
00:18:30:00 the bus tour passengers, including Len and Dorothy, bid each other farewell, followed by travelling by taxi to the airport and ‘Quantas’ and ‘Air New Zealand’ planes at the terminals

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film captures family holidays at Port Stephens, Point Roadknight and Ocean Grove, Victoria and Christmas in 1978. The family also goes fishing, plays tennis at the Geelong Lawn Tennis Club, attends a family wedding and enjoys some snow in Geelong.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Karen playing tennis
00:01:19:00 Karen sitting with a camera shy friend after the tennis
00:01:33:00 Dorothy and Stuart

00:05:27:00 an inflatable ‘Lilo’ mat on the water
00:06:36:00 posing for the camera with friends or relatives
00:07:58:00 scenes of the sea
00:10:05:00 late 1970s wedding in peachy coloured tones

00:14:57:00 Stuart in school uniform
00:15:16:00 family members fishing
00:19:10:00 an extended family gathering

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

In this film, the Nixon family are living in Alice Springs in 1966, until we see them returning to Victoria via a TAA flight. TAA (Trans Australian Airlines) was the major air service in the 1960s and 1970s flying to destinations all over Australian and its near neighbours of Papua New Guinea and Timor. One of the most memorable advertising jingles at the time was ‘Up, Up and away, with TAA, the Friendly, Friendly Way…’, a variation on the 1967 song Up, Up and Away, written by Jimmy Webb and also used by the US airline TWA.

At home in Herne Hill, new baby Stuart is introduced to the camera, in his ‘bassinette’, laughing at the camera, bouncing in a ‘bouncinette’, in his bath, in his ‘highchair’ and sitting on big sister Karen’s lap. The family spend time at the beach and Karen celebrates her fourth birthday.

Scenes of the Melbourne Zoo show the difference in standards for zoological practices between the 1960s and contemporary practices.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:23:00 view of houses in the arid setting of Alice Springs
00:01:15:00 mountain scenery seen across the scrubby desert
00:01:49:00 memorial for ‘Flynn of the Inland’
00:02:22:00 Dorothy wearing a very 1960s style ‘sunsuit’ for hot weather
00:02:30:00 children playing in a portable backyard swimming pool
00:03:16:00 views of rocks and a creek followed by Alice Springs township from a higher vantage point
00:04:50:00 (faint) carvings on a rock face
00:05:15:00 ‘John Flynn Church’
00:05:25:00 cars in Alice Springs
00:05:56:00 Karen wearing sunglasses
00:06:40:00 views around an Indigenous settlement
00:07:11:00 children eating watermelon
00:07:28:00 floods in the outback
00:07:45:00 TAA (Trans Australian Airlines) airplane on the tarmac at an outback airport
00:07:53:00 propeller of flying plane and views of the sea and land below, followed by landing scenes
00:08:51:00 scenes of baby Stuart at home in Herne Hill, Geelong
00:09:50:00 baby Stuart in a ‘bouncinette’ and in his ‘bassinette’
00:11:55:00 Les and Karen with baby Stuart
00:12:42:00 Dorothy in a Ford ‘Cortina’ model car
00:13:29:00 scenes at the beach
00:14:03:00 Karen and companion buried in the sand at the beach
00:15:48:00 scenes at the Melbourne Zoo
00:16:33:00 Karen’s fourth birthday celebrations
00:17:13:00 baby Stuart almost crawling across the carpet
00:18:08:00 Karen shows a popular activity of the time – the ‘hula hoop’
00:18:45:00 Stuart in a crate on the back of a bicycle
00:18:47:00 Karen shows off her ‘cowgirl’ outfit
00:19:17:00 baby Stuart walking
00:19:31:00 Karen and baby brother Stuart on a tricycle (trike)
00:21:00:00 baby Stuart walking with a toy lawn mower, on his tricycle and with Karen showing off a new outfit
00:21:37:00 at the beach and in the water
00:22:21:00 Dorothy and the children in new outfits in red and orange
00:23:06:00 late 1960s or early 1970s wedding
00:23:28:00 Les in 1970s style shorts and long socks
00:24:04:00 a ‘Victa’ brand lawn mower
00:25:30:00 garden scenes
00:25:40:00 a cricket game

results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Michaelis’s daughter, Sally Cohen, and her husband Sheldon Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This film is titled’ Eastern Tour 1939’ and begins with footage of a passenger liner departing from Sydney Harbour farewelled by waving onlookers and streamers. We see Sydney Harbour and images of the Whitsundays along the way. The highlight of this film is the footage of Bali in 1939. We see Balinese people in a traditional canoe, juking or cadik, paddle alongside the ship as it arrives in Bali. Once on land, there are images of temples, rice terraces, farmers, and a Balinese market with traders plying their trade. There are local people buying food from the stallholders and busying themselves around the market and socialising. We witness a Balinese wedding ceremony and a Gamelan orchestra accompanying a performance of the Legong Dance. The film also shows dancers preparing and dressing for a Djanger Dance Performance, and a Kris dance is performed by men and children on a dirt road in Bali.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

results.title: [Nicoll Family Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Nicoll Family Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm home movies made by Alexander (Alex) Nicoll from the 1930s to the 1960s. The films were donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s son Mac Nicoll.

Alex was gifted his camera from a wealthy mentor, Arthur Thomas, who also lent Alex money to establish a business. Alex began a lifelong involvement in the “rag trade”, running an import agency on the third floor at Tasmania House. He was a popular figure in “The Lane”, serving for some years as the President of the Victorian Softgoods Association.

Alex always deeply respected Arthur Thomas, keeping a framed photo of Thomas on his desk until he retired. Thomas was a keen photographer and when he died in the 1930s he left Alex his Agfa 16mm camera, his projector and collapsible screen, all of which Alex frequently used during the 1940s and 1950s. There were films galore: films of family at home and on holidays, of faraway places in his later years and local events. For example, he captured the excitement of the 1956 Olympics in Melbourne with footage of the decorated buildings in the city with the department stores of the era – Foy’s, Buckley’s, Myer, Coles and Woolworths. He was often asked to show his films at family events and other local gatherings.

Alex suffered a serious stroke in 1960, which caused the sale of his business and the end of his photography. He died in 1968 and the film equipment passed to his son, Mac, who continued filming the comings and goings of his young family in the 1960s to the early 1970s. Mac valued the support shown to his father and in his way, supported others by becoming a well-respected teacher.

results.title: [Phillip Annett Home Movie]
results.brief_description:
This home movie was originally created on 16mm film by Phillip Annett. It was donated to ACMI by Daryl Annett.

This film is a snap shot of suburban life in Melbourne. There are wonderful examples of fashion, inner-Melbourne street scenes, architecture and cars of the time. We see a children’s birthday party and backyard games under the Hills Hoist as well as neighbours chatting over the fence to passers-by in the street. Men in Australian Army and Air Force uniforms pose and smile for the camera, and there are scenes of a road trip to regional Victoria. We see a fire truck display, horse and harness riding as well as woodchopping displays at the Royal Melbourne Show. There are candid images of a horse event competitor in the stables area of the Royal Melbourne Show, as well as St Kilda Road buses and trams as they travel down the road. Black and white images of a horse and cart and a man in a bowler hat performing tricks is a fantastic moment in time.

Selected highlights list (timecodes from Access Overscan)

description_for_label:
This home movie was originally created on 16mm film by Phillip Annett. It was donated to ACMI by Daryl Annett.

This film is a snap shot of suburban life in Melbourne. There are wonderful examples of fashion, inner-Melbourne street scenes, architecture and cars of the time. We see a children’s birthday party and backyard games under the Hills Hoist as well as neighbours chatting over the fence to passers-by in the street. Men in Australian Army and Air Force uniforms pose and smile for the camera, and there are scenes of a road trip to regional Victoria. We see a fire truck display, horse and harness riding as well as woodchopping displays at the Royal Melbourne Show. There are candid images of a horse event competitor in the stables area of the Royal Melbourne Show, as well as St Kilda Road buses and trams as they travel down the road. Black and white images of a horse and cart and a man in a bowler hat performing tricks is a fantastic moment in time.

results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Michaelis’s daughter, Sally Cohen, and her husband Sheldon Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This film shows an amateur game fishing trip that appears to take place in Bermagui. We see images of the pier with people boarding the small boats and preparing for the fishing trip. Once they set sail, we see seals on the rocks and dolphins swimming alongside the boat. The fishing expedition is a great success. A 250lb marlin is caught and brought on board. The catch of the day is taken back to the pier and admired by impressed onlookers. It is weighed, hung from a wooden scaffold, and put on public display. The flank of the fish is tattooed with the name of the fisherman, (R. Michaels), the marlin’s weight and the date of the catch – 6 February 1938. Various locals stop by and pose with the fish to have their photos taken. In the background are vintage cars and a Shell petrol pump alongside a general store which offers hardware, motor accessories and fishing tackle.

This film shows fashion, cars, buildings and amateur fishing boats. It is a snapshot of game fishing and all that it entails in Bermagui.

Selected Highlights List (timecodes from Access Overscan)

00:08:00:00 people standing and walking along the pier; good details of the boats

00:48:00:00 a man is seen shooting film footage from a passing boat called Marlin

00:04:24:00 the marlin is pulled on to the deck
00:05:33:00 the fishing boat arrives back at the pier
00:05:56:00 the marlin is winched onto the pier watched by onlookers
00:06:23:00 weighing the marlin on the pier

00:07:44:00 a man stands and poses beside the hanging marlin
00:08:05:00 man stands beside hanging marlin in front of an old Shell petrol pump and Plume signage; General Hardware shop front advertising motor accessories and fishing tackle

results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Sheldon and Sally Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This film depicts scenes of Bali and Java taken while on a holiday in 1939. The film is divided into sections indicated by titles: ‘Native Law Court –The Ceiling is Decorated with Pictures of Punishments’; ‘A Balinese Beauty’; ‘A Temple Birthday Festival – The Procession’; ‘A Temple Birthday Festival – at the Temple’; ‘Polishing Rice’; ‘Cockfighting is a Popular Past time’; ‘Java’; ‘Java – Selecta-A Hill station above Soerabaja’; ‘Java Semarang’; ‘The Borobudur’; ‘A Mohammedan Funeral at Djockjakarta’; ‘Buitenzorg – Government House and the Botanical Gardens’.

This film is interesting for the Balinese and Javanese street, local transport and people scenes. Images of the architecture, temples, cultural traditions and ceremonies are also a highlight. The film shows pottery techniques and a pottery ware market. There is footage of a funeral procession and a traditional Balinese temple festival or Odalan. The film shows elaborate offerings of fruit and food which is brought with great ceremony by the locals to the temple. We see Borobudur and surrounds, including details of the temple walls and structure. Dutch spelling and place names, as well as images of the hill station resort Selecta, reflect Indonesia’s colonial history and provide context for the time in which the film was made.

results.title: [Noise] = Hearing conservation
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield, Dept of Science and Technology and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Serious hearing loss perpetrated in the industrial workplace is irreversible. This program portrays the peer pressures on the shop floor that might discourage workers from using protective devices - but at their peril. We see one factory worker who is teased about wearing his ear muffs, but his fantasies convince him that the consequences are worse than the flak he cops. A light-hearted drama which emphasises the necessity of using the correct protective gear at work. Stars Bryan Brown.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl McPhee, Tom Manefield, Dept of Science and Technology and Film Australia
